_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Operator check for ammonia leaks every four hours
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Anhydrous Ammonia



This process is a batch style process for a specific agricultural product. This system is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit  the amount of ammonia held in the storage tank. The unloading of ammonia tank trucks is also governed by Plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.  Ammonia pump (10-110-045B)



The storage tank is housed in a concrete diked area. All nozzles on the tank are fitted with excess flow valves except for nozzles with pressure relief valves. A local level indicator is available on the tank with a transmitter conveying  the level measurement into the control room. This instrument is used to monitor and control the tank level.



The pressure relief valves are tested annually. The entire system undergoes annual maintenance which includes: external inspection, checks for any leaks, bolt tightness on the manway. 



Ammonia is transferred to an ammonia / water mixer to prepare a solution that is pumped to a surge tank . The solution is then pumped to the chemical processing equipment and used to manufacture an agricultural product.



All changes to this system fall under the Plant's process safety management of change procedure. Hazard reviews are conducted for all changes.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Cylinders being used in the process are handled inside a building (the vaporizer building).
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Cl2 analyzer interlocked to building exhaust fan.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Chlorine is transported to the plant site in one ton cylinders. These cylinders are transported on a flat-bed truck trailer equipped with a boom for off loading. One ton cylinders are widely available and are used in variety of industries. The chlorine supplier owns and maintains the cylinders.



The cylinders are off loaded with the boom and placed into cradles designed to transport and store the cylinders. The cradles are equipped with rollers for correctly orienting the cylinder valves and are also equipped with the means to securely lock the cylinder in place on the cradle. A forklift truck is used to transport the cylinder and  cradle to the cylinder storage shed. The shed is designed to protect the cylinders from the weather.



The forklift truck is also used to move the cylinders to the vaporizer building when chlorine is needed in the manufacturing process. One cylinder will be connected to the vaporization process equipment at a time. A maximum of eight cylinders will be allowed in the dispensing or vaporizer building at any time.



Unique pipe fittings are utilized to ensure that only chlorine is transferred to the process. The piping system is designed to minimize potential leak spots.



The chlorine vaporizer or dispensing building is inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems. It is also monitored continuously for chlorine leaks. If a leak is detected, the system will alarm, shutdown the transfer equipment, and automatically start ventilating  equipment. Trained operating staff will respond accordingly.



The chlorine transfer system and processing equipment are equipped with instruments for monitoring the process. The system is designed to prevent events such as tank overfilling and over pressurization. The process is monitored  continuously by control and interlock systems as well as trained operating personnel. A relatively low chlorine inventory in maintained in the process vessels. It reacts immediately.



This process operating procedures and administrative controls are designed to limit the chlorine inventory in the storage shed and dispensing buildings.  The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.



All changes fall under the Plant's process safety management of change procedure. Hazard reviews are conducted for all changes.

Acrylonitrile shipments are unloaded from top unloading bulk trailers into its storage tank. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leak spots by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by utilizing the redundant equipment such as rupture disk followed by a relief valve.



All fumes from the unloading process, storage tank and process are neutralized in a scrubber.  The scrubber has multiple layers of redundancy, including emergency power, to ensure continuous operation.  The tank farm area and process building are inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems.



The secondary containment area for the storage tank is designed to hold or contain 110% of the storage tank volume.  Unique bulk container fittings (connectors)  are used to ensure that only the correct raw material can be unloaded into a given storage tank. Unloading procedures are used to lock out and disable all non-participating unloading equipment.



The unloading system, storage tank and processing equipment are equipped with the instruments for monitoring process variables. The system is designed to prevent events such as tank over filling and over pressurization. The unloading process and storage tank is monitored continuously by control and interlock systems. In addition, the process is also monitored continuously by highly trained operating personnel.



This process is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit  the amount of materials held in the storage tank. The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.



All changes fall under the plant's process safety management of change procedure. Hazard reviews are conducted for all changes.

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Daily Tank & Equipment inspection & leak check
_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Computer based simulation of control systems
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Bromine, phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride are unloaded from top unloading bulk trailers into their respective storage tanks. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leak spots by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by utilizing the redundant equipment such as rupture disk followed by a relief valve.  All fumes from the unloading process,  storage tanks and process are neutralized in a scrubber.  The scrubber has multiple layers of redundancy, including emergency power, to ensure continuous operation.The tank farm area and process building are inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems.

Reactor (130-051)

Pump (110-020)

Reactor (120-001)

Reactor (150-001)

Pump (110-029)



The secondary containment areas for each storage tank are designed to hold or contain 110% of the storage tank volumes. Unique bulk containers and unloading stations are utilized to ensure that only the correct raw material can be unloaded into a given storage tank. Unloading procedures lock out and disable all non-participating unloading equipment.



The unloading system, storage tank and processing equipment are equipped with the instruments for monitoring process variables. The system is designed to prevent events such as tank over filling and over pressurization. The unloading process and storage tanks are monitored continuously by control and interlock systems. In addition, the process is also monitored continuously by trained operating personnel.



This process is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit  the amount of materials held in the storage tank. The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by Plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.



All changes fall under the Plant's process safety management of change procedure. Hazard reviews are conducted for all changes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
At BASF Corporation's Hannibal Plant (Site), we manufacture several agricultural products.  At this Site, our focus is on protecting our employees, the families that live in nearby communities, and the environment.



We have designed our process areas to safely manage the chemicals used and produced by our production facilities. It is our policy to not only to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations but also to voluntarily go beyond these requirements to ensure our continued successful and safe operations, most notably as a Responsible Care Company.  We have developed and implemented the following to help achieve our goals:



* State of the art process equipment and process control design incorporating safety devices and systems needed to properly handle, store or use materials in our processes

* Well-defined and documented operating procedures and control systems

* A well-defined safety, health and process safety management system

* Well-trained production employees coupled to a trained technical staff

* An extensive preventive maintenance and equipment inspection program

* Site access is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and authorized contractors



In addition to these preventative programs, it is the Site's policy to maintain an emergency response plan and trained personnel and response equipment to be prepared to respond to potential emergencies involving fire, releases of hazardous material, medical emergencies, and confined space rescue. The Site coordinates with area, community, emergency-response agencies providing them with information on operations and response programs in addition to  frequent interaction/communication  with members of the local emergency response agencies.



The Site has seven substances that exceed the RMP threshold quantities.  These compounds are acrylonitrile, anhydrous ammonia, bromine, chlorine, phosphorus oxychloride, phosphorus trichloride and trimethylamine.  T

rimethylamine is classified as a flammable material. The other materials are classified as toxic substances. All of these are used as raw materials to produce agricultural products.



Acrylonitile



Acrylonitrile, a liquid, is shipped to the Site by tank truck (about 40,000 pounds per tank truck). During unloading, the truck is stationed in a containment area designed to hold 110% of the truck's contents. Acrylonitrile is unloaded via top unloading system into its storage tank. A designed tank truck and unloading station are used to ensure that only the correct raw material is unloaded into the storage tank. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leaks by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by using the latest control devices.



The acrylonitrile storage tank is housed in a secondary containment area. It is pumped to the chemical processing equipment to make the agricultural products. A scrubber destroys all fumes from the unloading operation, the storage tank and the chemical processing steps. The total plant inventory is about 66,000 pounds. This total includes the maximum allowable acrylonitrile in the storage tank, in pipes & hoses, and the amount in the chemical process.



Ammonia



Liquid, anhydrous ammonia is received by tank truck (approximately 26,000 pounds per truck) and is stored in a single steel tank at ambient temperature and under its own vapor pressure. This tank is located within a concrete secondary containment system.  The tank is equipped with overpressure protection and is rated to withstand full vacuum. The total ammonia inventory is 55,000 pounds. This includes the amount in the storage tank and associated piping that handle anhydrous ammonia. 



The anhydrous ammonia handling system consists of an unloading station with secondary containment system, a storage tank, two pumps and piping.  As for all operations at this facility, this system is governed by well-established operating procedures.



Bromine



Bromin

e, a liquid, is shipped to the plant by tank truck (about 40,000 pounds per truck). During unloading, the truck is stationed in a containment area designed to hold 110% of the truck's contents. Bromine is unloaded via top unloading system into its storage tank. A designed tank truck and unloading station are used to ensure that only the correct raw material is unloaded into the storage tank. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leaks by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by using the latest control devices.



The bromine storage tank is housed in a diked area. It is pumped to the chemical processing equipment to make the agricultural products. A scrubber destroys all fumes from the unloading operation, the storage tank and the chemical processing steps. The total plant inventory is about 100,000 pounds. This total includes the maximum allowable bromine in the storage tank and the amount in the chemical process.



Chlorine



Chlorine is shipped to the Site in one ton cylinders. One ton cylinders are widely available and are used in a variety of industries. Upon receipt, the cylinders are placed into specially designed cradles and transported to a cylinder storage shed for weather protection. When needed, the cylinders are moved to a separate building which houses a chlorine dispensing system which vaporizes the chlorine and conveys it to the chemical manufacturing process where it is consumed. One cylinder is connected to the dispensing system at a time. A maximum of eight cylinders is allowed in the dispensing building including the one being used. The maximum number of cylinders allowed on the Site site is twenty. The total Site inventory is 50,000 pounds.



Phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride



Phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride is also transported to the Site via tank truck. Both are liquids and are stored and handled in the same manner as bromine. Each tank truckload is about 40,000 pounds. During unlo

ading, each truck is stationed in a containment area designed to hold 110% of the truck's contents. A designed tank truck and unloading station are also used to ensure that only the correct raw material is unloaded into its designated storage tank.



The storage tanks for phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride are installed in a diked area. Each material is pumped to the chemical processing equipment to make the agricultural products. A scrubber destroys all fumes from the unloading operation, the storage tank and the chemical processing steps. The total unit inventory of phosphorus oxychloride is about 100,000 pounds. The total plant inventory of phosphorus trichloride is about 74,000 pounds.



Trimethylamine



Trimethylamine (TMA) is shipped to the Site in bulk trailers. Each shipment is about 40,000 pounds. TMA is shipped under pressure in the bulk trailer. Unique pipefittings are used to ensure that only the correct material is unloaded into the TMA storage tank. TMA is transferred to the chemical process to make an intermediate for an agricultural product. The total Site inventory is 83,000 pounds.



The Site has a well-established accident prevention program. The primary purpose of the program is to eliminate those events which have the potential to result in personal injury, property loss and environmental or community impact. The secondary purpose of the program is to ensure reliable and predictable operations. The objective of the program is to eliminate all unexpected events. The program consists of four fundamental elements: (1) written procedures; (2) training; (3) auditing; (4) process reviews or evaluation.



(1) The written procedures include personal health and safety, work practices, equipment operation, loss prevention, and related topics. The procedures are implemented using administrative, engineering and personal protective equipment controls. The procedures receive periodic review and are revised as necessary.



(2) The trainin

g element includes job specific safety, emergency response and hazard awareness training. Training plans are specifically developed for various employee groups. The frequency of the training varies within a three-year cycle depending upon the employee group and the topic.



(3) The auditing activities include both internal and external audits.  Internal audits are completed using a wide range of Site resources.  Site personnel conduct routine general inspections of Site facilities on a regular basis (e.g. daily/weekly/monthly).  Site and Corporate personnel conduct  plant-wide audits at a minimum three-year frequency.   These audits include safety, housekeeping, transportation, ergonomics, emergency systems, industrial hygiene, process safety management and mechanical integrity inspections.  Corporate and Division staff, state and federal agencies, insurance companies, etc. also conduct external audits.



(4) Process Hazard Analyses are completed for each manufacturing and related support facilities on a 5-year cycle in accordance with applicable OSHA Process Safety Management regulations. Selected management of change activities also requires a hazard analysis. The analyses evaluate the impact of unexpected events to both in-plant and off-plant receptors.



Five-year accident history: The Site maintains records of all chemical releases. Our records document that we have had no accidental releases of the RMP-listed substances meeting the RMP rule criteria for the past five years.



The Site also has a well-established emergency response plan. Its primary purpose is to guide Site personnel during emergency situations. The secondary purpose is to communicate to the surrounding communities and area response agencies how the Site intends to respond to potential emergency situations. The plan's objective is to provide a coordinated response to potential Site emergencies that could threaten employee health and safety, the local community, the environment or Site prope

rty.



The Site maintains experienced personnel who are fully trained to respond to potential emergencies arising from fires, hazardous material releases, and medical emergencies and confined space incidents. The various teams are equipped to respond to Site emergencies.  The Site recognizes the potential need to utilize community emergency response agencies during some emergency situations. Therefore, Site emergency response teams coordinate with members of the Palmyra, Hannibal, Quincy and Hannibal Rural Fire Departments sharing Site response information. 



The Site has an effective safety program as indicated by its excellent safety performance record.  The Site has implemented effective programs to minimize the potential for off-site releases. At this time, there are no specific changes planned for the safety program related to the RMP activities. The Site's Operations Leadership Team and Responsible Care Steering Group meet on a regular basis to evaluate performance and to modify and improve the Safety and Environmental programs, as needed.
